Headline: A bit disappointed you retired, wanted you to go past 619: Anil Kumble to AshwinAnil Kumble shared his retirement message for Ravichandran Ashwin after the veteran spinner called it a time on his international career. Ashwin ended his career as India's 2nd highest wicket-taker in Tests after Kumble.
Content:
Former India spinner Anil Kumble expressed his disappointment with Ravichandran Ashwin as the veteran player announced his retirement from international cricket on December 18, Wednesday. The disappointment, however, stemmed from Ashwin not surpassing Kumble's record tally of 619 Test wickets. Ashwin called time on his international career after India's third Test against Australia ended in a draw at The Gabba. Day 5 witnessed heavy rains, preventing the match from proceeding further. The Border-Gavaskar Trophy series remained tied at 1-1. What followed next was nothing short of a shock, as Ashwin announced his retirement. "Congratulations, Ash, on a fantastic career. You’ve been a champion bowler for India, a champion all-rounder for India. You’ll certainly be missed. It’s not that easy, carrying that kind of expectation day in and day out. You’ve done it right throughout your career. You’ve been a match-winner for India, and Team India will certainly miss you," Kumble said in a video shared by ESPNcricinfo.Ashwin brings curtains down to his career Ashwin, earlier, had mentioned that he would retire the moment he reached the 618-wicket mark as a tribute to Kumble, India’s highest wicket-taker in Tests. However, the veteran ended his career with 537 Test wickets, securing his place as India’s second-highest wicket-taker in the format. "I, for one, am a bit disappointed that you ended your career today at the international level. Ideally, I would have wanted to see you go beyond 619, but you have your reasons for that," Kumble added.Kumble's wish for Ashwin Kumble also wished Ashwin the best of luck for his future endeavours. "All the best to you in your second chapter. And I am sure it will be as glorious as chapter one. So, Ash, here’s to a fantastic career that you’ve had for India. And congratulations once again. All the very best. Catch you soon," Kumble concluded. R Ashwin made the bold call to retire from international cricket mid-way through the Border-Gavaskar Trophy in Australia on Wednesday, The rumours started to circulate during Day 5 of the Gabba Test when Ashwin was seen sharing a hug with Virat Kohli in the dressing room. He then made his way to the post-match press conference alongside Rohit Sharma and quickly announced his retirement and left.

Headline: Hunt for WTC Final begins as South Africa announces Test squad vs PakistanSouth Africa has announced its 16-man squad for the upcoming Test series against Pakistan, set to begin on December 26 in Centurion, with a clear focus on securing a place in next year's World Test Championship (WTC) final.
Content: South Africa has announced its 16-man squad for the upcoming Test series against Pakistan, set to begin on December 26 in Centurion, with a clear focus on securing a place in next year’s World Test Championship (WTC) final. The squad sees the inclusion of Keshav Maharaj and Wiaan Mulder, both of whom are recovering from injuries, while also offering opportunities to uncapped players like Corbin Bosch and Kwena Maphaka. Maharaj, who was forced to miss the first ODI against Pakistan due to an acute groin strain sustained during warm-ups, will undergo a scan to assess the injury's severity. His inclusion in the Test squad comes despite this setback, with Cricket South Africa (CSA) closely monitoring his recovery. Meanwhile, Mulder is returning to full fitness after a fractured right middle finger ruled him out of the second Test against Sri Lanka. The all-rounder has completed the final phase of his recovery and will provide additional depth to the South African squad. If Mulder is selected for the first Test, batter Matthew Breetzke will be released from the squad. In a significant move, 30-year-old seamer Corbin Bosch has earned his first call-up to the Test team. Bosch has impressed with his all-round performances in domestic cricket, taking 72 wickets at an average of 36.75 across 34 first-class matches, while also contributing with the bat. His selection follows strong performances for the SA Invitational XI against England Lions, where he claimed 1-21. Alongside Bosch, uncapped seamer Kwena Maphaka retains his place in the squad after being part of the group for the second Test against Sri Lanka. South Africa Test squad Temba Bavuma (captain), David Bedingham, Corbin Bosch, Matthew Breetzke, Tony de Zorzi, Marco Jansen, Keshav Maharaj, Kwena Maphaka, Aiden Markram, Wiaan Mulder, Senuran Muthusamy, Dane Paterson, Kagiso Rabada, Ryan Rickelton, Tristan Stubbs, Kyle Verreynne (wk). CSA head coach Shukri Conrad expressed confidence in the squad's ability to challenge Pakistan, with the pace attack seen as one of the team's strongest assets. "We are excited to see Corbin make his step up to Test cricket. His all-round ability adds depth to our attack, and his pace brings an extra bite. We’re also closely monitoring Keshav's injury and hope it won’t be too serious," said Conrad. South Africa enters the series with a clear objective — a win over Pakistan would bring them a step closer to securing a place in the World Test Championship Final. With one more victory needed to guarantee a spot, the Proteas are eager to extend their lead at the top of the WTC standings. “We’re focused on the task at hand — a spot in the World Test Championship Final is the ultimate goal. This series against Pakistan will be a tough challenge, especially with their talented fast bowlers, but we believe our squad is well-equipped for the task," Conrad added. The first Test against Pakistan will be played at SuperSport Park in Centurion, with the second Test taking place at Cape Town in the New Year. South Africa's batters, who stood up during the series against Sri Lanka, will be keen to showcase their skills against a quality Pakistan bowling attack in the upcoming series.Published By: Kingshuk KusariPublished On: Dec 18, 2024Also Read |  Watch: Retiring R Ashwin's emotional parting speech at Gabba dressing roomMust Watch

Headline: D Gukesh reveals how he plans to spend Rs 11.45 crore world championship prize Chess prodigy D Gukesh shares insight into the world champion's plan for the Rs 11.45 crore prize money. The 18-year-old's  parents made huge sacrifices in his journey to the top.
Content: World champion D Gukesh recently revealed his plans for the whopping prize money of Rs 11.45 crore after his historic victory over Ding Liren, which made him the youngest world champion in the history of chess. The 18-year-old's journey to the pinnacle of chess has been deeply influenced by the unwavering support of his parents, who made immense sacrifices to nurture his passion for the game. Chess, being an expensive sport, required significant financial investment, and Gukesh shared how his parents dedicated all their resources to ensure he could pursue his dreams. When the family faced financial difficulties, it was the generosity of his parents’ friends—who stepped in to sponsor him—that allowed him to continue his chess journey. "First of all, I am very happy for my parents. They had to struggle a lot for me. They burnt all their bridges so I could pursue my passion. They faced severe financial challenges," Gukesh exclusively told Sports Today. "It was my parents' friends, their college mates, who sponsored us when we were struggling financially. Going through all these struggles and achieving this financial stability now, for my parents and their friends, means so much to me."Watch the video here-  Gukesh's parents, Rajnikanth and Padmakumari, would ensure that their son could chase his dream by making a lot of sacrifices. Rajnikanth gave up a lucrative career as an ENT surgeon to accompany Gukesh to tournaments, while Padmakumari, a microbiologist, became the family's sole earner.What Gukesh will do with prize money Reflecting on the significance of his achievement, he added, "To have given this peace to my parents—it means a lot to me. Personally, I never really thought too much about money, but I understand it is a very important part of life. I will use this amazing gift that God has given us to improve ourselves and to help us reach our full potential." Gukesh won the title after beating Liren in the final game of the World Chess Championship with a scoreline of 7.5-6.5. Headline: Coach Andrew Flintoff calls up son Rocky for England LionsEngland Lions head coach Andrew Flintoff has called-up his son Rocky for the team's tour of Australia. Rocky, who is 16, made his first class debut in 2024.
Content: England Lions head coach Andrew Flintoff has called up his son Rocky for the England Lions' tour of Australia in January 2025. England Lions announced their squad on Wednesday, 18 December, where the 16-year-old received his call-up. Rocky, who signed his first professional contract with Lancashire in June, got a late call-up to the Lions squad earlier this month in South Africa - the first tour of Andrew after being named the team's head coach in September. The Lions squad also includes five players from the senior team - Shoaib Bashir, Pat Brown, Tom Hartley, Josh Tongue, and John Turner. England will travel to Australia on Jan. 3 for two four-day matches against a Cricket Australia XI in Brisbane, followed by a first-class test against Australia A in Sydney. Former England all-rounder Andrew Flintoff was named as the head coach of the England Lions men's team. Flintoff, who has been in and around the national side as a coaching staff member, will now oversee the development of the young and upcoming stars pushing for the national team. England Lions is the country's A side where cricketers travel worldwide to participate in A tours. The England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB) announced their decision on September 7 via an official statement. The all-rounder will step into the role this October, succeeding in his mission to develop and mentor the next generation of English cricket talent.Who is Rocky Flintoff? Rocky Flintoff, born on April 7, 2008, is the son of the renowned English cricketer and television personality Andrew Flintoff. Rocky began his cricketing journey at Alderley Edge Cricket Club in Cheshire and later played for St Annes Cricket Club in 2020. His talent and dedication quickly earned him a place in the Lancashire County Cricket Club, where he made his debut for the second XI in April 2024, just two days after his 16th birthday. This debut was marked by an unbeaten half-century against Durham's second XI, and he soon followed this up with his first century for Lancashire's second XI against Warwickshire, scoring 116 from 165 balls. This feat made him the youngest player to score a century for Lancashire, surpassing the record previously held by his father, Andrew Flintoff. Rocky's junior career in internationals has also been impressive. In June 2024, he was called up to the England Under-19 cricket team and quickly made his mark. He scored a match-winning 106 in a warm-up match against a Young Lions Invitational XI and later scored a century in the second four-day match against Sri Lanka, becoming the youngest player to achieve this feat for England U19s at just 16 years and 102 days old. In addition to his second XI and international successes, Rocky made his List A debut for Lancashire in the One-Day Cup against Kent in July 2024, becoming the youngest-ever player for the team at 16 years and 113 days. He also made his first-class debut in the County Championship for Lancashire against Surrey in August 2024, the youngest player to do so for the county. Rocky's family life is also noteworthy. He is one of four children to Andrew Flintoff and his wife Rachael Wools Flintoff, along with siblings Holly, Corey, and Preston. His brother Corey also plays cricket for the Lancashire academy, indicating a strong cricketing legacy within the family. In June 2024, Rocky signed his first professional contract with Lancashire, a significant milestone in his burgeoning career. His performances have garnered widespread attention, and he is widely regarded as one of the most promising young cricketers in England. With his early achievements and the support of his cricketing family, Rocky Flintoff is poised to make a lasting impact in the world of cricket. Headline: Smriti Mandhana eyes T20I history in series decider vs West IndiesIND-W vs WI-W: Smriti Mandhana has the chance of making the record for most runs in Women's T20Is in a calendar year. Currently, she has 686 runs from 22 matches at an average of 40.35.
Content: Smriti Mandhana is on the cusp of making a massive record in T20Is when India and West Indies face off in the third and final match on Thursday, December 19 at the Dr DY Patil Sports Academy in Navi Mumbai. The left-handed batter is on the verge of making the record for most runs in Women’s T20Is in a calendar year. Currently, Sri Lankan captain Chamari Athapaththu holds the record, having scored 720 runs this year at an average of 40 and with two centuries and a top score of 119 not out. Mandhana is only 34 runs short of the landmark. In 22 T20Is this year, she has scored 686 runs at an average of 40.35 with seven fifties to her name. UAE’s Esha Oza (711 in 2024), West Indies captain Hayley Mathews (700 in 2023), and UAE’s Kavisha Egodage (696 in 2022) also feature in the list. Earlier, Mandhana also broke Harmanpreet Kaur’s record for most runs by an Indian in Women’s T20Is in a calendar year.Most runs in Women’s T20Is in a calendar year  Chamari Athapaththu – 720 runs from 21 matches (2024) Esha Oza - 711 runs from 20 matches (2024) Hayley Mathews – 700 from 14 matches (2023) Kavisha Egodage – 696 runs from 27 matches (2022) Smriti Mandhana – 686 runs from 22 matches (2024) Esha Oza – 675 runs from 25 matches (2022)Smriti Mandhana in brilliant form  Mandhana has been on top of her game in the T20I series against the West Indies. She is currently the top run-scorer in the series, having scored 116 runs from two games at an average of 58. Mandhana began the series with a 54-run knock, helping India take a 1-0 series lead. She made 62 on Tuesday, but India slumped to a nine-wicket defeat. Recently, she also notched an ODI hundred against Australia at the WACA in Perth.Published By: sabyasachi chowdhuryPublished On: Dec 18, 2024Also Read |  Smriti Mandhana gives verdict on RCB's picks in WPL 2025 auctionMust Watch

Headline: Why 'all format star' R Ashwin should not just be remembered for his Test heroicsAs Ravichandran Ashwin calls it a time on his international career, the veteran spinner shouldn't just be remembered for his wizardry in the longest format of the game. Let us recall some of Ashwin's memorable performances in the blue jersey for India.
Content:
When Ravichandran Ashwin first broke into the Indian Test team in 2011, he faced considerable criticism. Many viewed him as a 'white-ball specialist,' doubting his ability to succeed in the rigours of Test cricket. Yet as Ashwin bids farewell to all formats of the game, he leaves behind a legacy as one of the greatest Test players. But let’s not overlook the legend’s invaluable contributions to white-ball cricket. While Ashwin’s mastery of long spells and his role as the spearhead of India’s bowling attack during their dominant run at home since 2015 are celebrated, his white-ball heroics—often in tandem with MS Dhoni’s brilliance behind the stumps—are equally unforgettable.The Champions Trophy 2013 Final In the rain-marred final of the 2013 Champions Trophy, Ravichandran Ashwin showcased nerves of steel and a wizardry with the ball that scipted his name into Indian cricket folklore. Tasked with defending a modest 129, Ashwin rose to the occasion, delivering a spell that turned the tide in India’s favor.   Opening his account with remarkable precision, Ashwin struck twice in successive overs, dismissing Jonathan Trott and Joe Root to derail England’s chase. His first two overs yielded just six runs and two wickets, an exceptional effort in a high-stakes encounter. As the tension mounted, Ashwin bowled a game-changing maiden in his third over, which tightened the noose around England’s batting lineup.  When the equation boiled down to England needing 15 off the final over, MS Dhoni entrusted Ashwin to deliver under immense pressure. True to his reputation, the spinner showcased remarkable composure, outwitting the batters with his variations and taking India to a thrilling five-run victory.   Ashwin’s brilliant 2/15 was more than just figures; it was a defining performance that secured India the Champions Trophy title and reaffirmed his stature as a match-winner in clutch moments.

Headline: From James Anderson to R Ashwin: Legends who retired in 20242024 has been a tough year for cricket fans. Several exceptional cricketers have retired this year leaving a gaping hole in the cricketing world. From James Anderson to Ravichandran Ashwin, here's a list of players that retired in 2024.
Content: India spinner Ravichandran Ashwin called time on his illustrious international career on Wednesday, 18 December. Ashwin's shock decision came after India drew the 3rd Test match of the Border-Gavaskar Trophy. While the decision saw massive reactions from the cricketing world, many criticised the timing of the decision. 2024 has been a year where several top-notch cricketers have called time in their careers. The likes of James Anderson, Shikhar Dhawan and Tim Southee have hogged the limelight for the toughest decision of their respective careers. Also Read: When Rohit convinced Ashwin to play in Adelaide Here's a list of some of the elite cricketers who retired from one or multiple formats of international cricket in 2024.James Anderson England were planning James Anderson's farewell for months. The fast bowler was given his final Test match at the Lord's against West Indies. Anderson's family members rang the bell before the match as the fast bowler entered the ground for the final time. Anderson retired from all forms of international cricket on July 12, 2024, having taken 704 Test wickets.David Warner Australia batter David Warner was the first big retirement of the year. The opener called time after playing his final Test match in Sydney against Pakistan. Warner called it quits as one of the greatest all-format batters of the game on January 6, 2024.Virat Kohli, Rohit Sharma, Ravindra Jadeja (T20I) India legends Virat Kohli, Rohit Sharma and Ravindra Jadeja retired from the T20I format of the game after winning the T20 World Cup 2024. The decision came one after the other with Indian fans hailing the trio as one of the greatest in the modern generation. The farewell was especially emotional for Virat Kohli, who played a gem of a knock to get India out of trouble in the final match of the tournament. Border-Gavaskar Trophy: Full CoverageNeil Wagner A true workhorse and one of the most fiercest fast bowlers from New Zealand - Neil Wagner announced his retirement from international cricket on February 27, 2024. Wagner was picked in the squad for the two-Test series against Australia starting in Wellington on Thursday but was told by selectors he would not feature in either the opener or the second match in Christchurch. Wagner's greatest accomplishment was perhaps his role in New Zealand's win in the inaugural World Test Championship.Tim Southee (Test) New Zealand pacer Tim Southee called it time on his Test career after the England Test series. After playing a key role in New Zealand's 423-run win in the third and final Test of a home series against England at Seddon Park in Hamilton. Southee was given a guard of honour before he spoke at a farewell ceremony attended by Sir Richard Hadlee. The right-arm fast bowler brought an end to a 17-year-long career with 391 Test wickets. He finished second only to Hadlee, who has 431 wickets at the top of the all-time wicket-takers list for New Zealand.Dinesh Karthik Dinesh Karthik officially announced his retirement from all forms of cricket - including the Indian Premier League on June 1. Karthik said he took the call after long deliberation. The wicketkeeper-batter took to social media on his 39th birthday and confirmed he was making the decision to retire 'official'. Notably, quite a few had started sending in congratulatory messages to Karthik after his final IPL game, but the cricketer confirmed he thought long and hard before making the final call.Shikhar Dhawan Former India cricketer Shikhar Dhawan announced his retirement from domestic and international cricket on August 24. Dhawan last played for India in the ODI series against Bangladesh in December 2022 before losing his place to Shubman Gill. The 38-year-old shared a long video message for his fans on his social media handles thanking them for their love and support throughout his career.Moeen Ali England's all-rounder Moeen Ali announced his retirement from international cricket. His decision came after he was snubbed from England's white-ball squad for the upcoming series against Australia. His last appearance for England was in the semi-final against India in the ICC Men's T20 World Cup on June 27 in Guyana. Moeen, 37, realised that it was the right time for him to call it a time on his international career and let the youngsters take over the reins of England cricket. "I'm 37 years old and didn't get picked for this month's Australia series," Moeen said in a Daily Mail interview. "I've played a lot of cricket for England. It's time for the next generation, which was also explained to me. It felt like the time was right. I've done my part, Moeen added, who made his international debut for England in 2014.Shakib Al Hasan (T20I) While Shakib Al Hasan has never explicitly retired from Test cricket, he did publicly announce that he would like to retire after playing his farewell Test match against South Africa in Mirpur. However, the legendary all-rounder was not able to return to Bangladesh to play the Test match due to an arrest warrant on his name. Headline: Halep, Hewitt's son get wildcard for Australian Open 2025 qualifiers Australian Open 2025: Former World No.1 Simona Halep and Lleyton Hewitt's son Cruz have been included as wildcards for the qualifying round for the hard court major at Melbourne Park.
Content:

Halep, also a former champion at Wimbledon and French Open, has faced troubles after consuming the banned drug roxadustat. Halep was suspended for four years back in 2022, after which the suspension period was increased to four years. But back in March 2024, the Court of Arbitration for Sport reduced it to nine months. The 33-year-old then returned to the court in March where she took part in the Miami Open. Halep sounded excited on her return to Melbourne Park. "I have been working hard to get ready for the 2025 season. The Australian Open has provided me with some of the best moments in my career, so I can't wait to be back in Melbourne and playing in front of the Aussie fans,” Halep, who is currently ranked No.877  in the world, said.

Headline: R Ashwin's retirement shocks Brad Haddin, Brett LeeIND vs AUS: India spinner Ravichandran Ashwin's retirement shocked several former cricketers. Former Australia stars Brad Haddin and Brett Lee wondered why Ashwin decided to leave in the middle of the Australia tour.
Content: India spinner Ravichandran Ashwin's shock retirement baffled former Australian cricketers Brad Haddin and Brett Lee. Ashwin, who announced his decision after the conclusion of the Gabba Test match on Wednesday, 18 December, said that he would reveal more details about his retirement call later. Haddin and Brett Lee, speaking during the Border-Gavaskar Trophy's 3rd Test match, speculated if everything was right in that Indian dressing room. Haddin, while speaking to Fox Cricket said that Ashwin might have been frustrated given India used three spinners in the first three Test matches of the series, out of which he only played one in Adelaide. “More will come out when Ashwin has his opportunity to speak; just reading between the lines, it looked like he may have been a bit frustrated with the spinning options that they’ve changed in the first three Test matches,” Brad Haddin told Fox Cricket after his press conference. “To me, he was a student of the game (and) always looking at ways to get better ... he’s earned the right.” Border-Gavaskar Trophy: Full Coverage Former Australia cricketer compared Ashwin's retirement to that of Graeme Swann who called it quits during the infamous 2013-14 Ashes, where England were rolled over by Australia Down Under. “I think the last time a spinner retired through a series (in Australia) was Graeme Swann,” said Lee. “He may have been told that he’s not going to play any further part in this series, and rightly so, (he) just decided to go out on his own terms.” Also Read: When Rohit convinced Ashwin to play in Adelaide Legendary former cricketer Sunil Gavaskar was critical of Ashwin's decision and said that Ashwin's choice to leave mid-series leaves India short of one key cricketer. “He could have said, listen after the end of the series, I won’t be available for selection for India. What it does is that, similarly when MS Dhoni retired at the end of the third Test in 2014-15 series, it leaves you one short. The selection committee has picked so many players for a tour with a purpose. If there are any injuries, they can select from the reserve players to have in the team.” Gavaskar told broadcasters. “So, Sydney is somewhere where there is a lot of support on offer for spinners. Headline: Manchester United are better with Rashford: Manager Ruben Amorim amid exit talksManchester United manager Ruben Amorim said that the Premier League club are "better" with Marcus Rashford after the forward suggested he could leave Old Trafford.
Content: Manchester United manager Ruben Amorim firmly stated that the club is "better with Marcus Rashford," after the England forward's remarks suggested he might seek a new challenge in his career. Rashford, 27, ignited speculation about his future on Tuesday during a visit to his old school, where he hinted at being "ready for the next steps." The timing of the statement raised eyebrows as it came just days after he was left out of the squad for United's dramatic 2-1 derby win over Manchester City at the Etihad Stadium. When asked about Rashford's remarks, Amorim struck a composed yet emphatic tone. "I don't talk about the future; we talk about the present," he said during the pre-match press conference for Thursday's League Cup quarter-final against Tottenham Hotspur. "We are better with Marcus Rashford. This kind of club needs big talents - and he is a big talent." Having been with the club since the age of seven, Rashford is synonymous with United's identity. He has made 426 appearances since his debut in 2016, scoring 138 goals and winning the Europa League, two FA Cups, and two League Cups. However, his form has dipped in recent seasons. Despite a stellar 2022-23 campaign with 30 goals in 56 matches, Rashford managed just eight goals in 43 appearances last term, marking the lowest shot conversion rate of his career at 9.4%. This season, his appearances have been sporadic, with his last Premier League start coming in a 4-0 win against Everton on December 1, where he scored twice. Amorim acknowledged the forward's recent struggles but expressed unwavering confidence in his ability to regain top form. "We will try different things to push Rashford to the best levels that he has shown me in the past," he said. Rashford's exclusion from the derby squad, along with 20-year-old Argentine winger Alejandro Garnacho, sparked questions about Amorim's approach. The Portuguese manager explained his decisions as part of a larger effort to enforce high standards across the squad. "I have to make choices based on what I see in training," Amorim stated. "Rashford and Garnacho are in the same situation as every other player. If they train well, they'll be considered for selection." While Rashford's comments about seeking a new challenge might suggest a potential exit, Amorim framed the situation differently, urging his players to embrace the "new challenge" of restoring Manchester United to its former glory. "For me, this is the biggest challenge in football because we are in a difficult situation," Amorim said. "I really hope all my players are ready for this new challenge." Amorim also reiterated his desire to see Rashford thrive within the team, emphasizing the importance of the forward's contribution. "What I want is to take the best of Marcus Rashford. He just needs to perform at the highest level, and that's my focus," he added.Published By: Saurabh KumarPublished On: Dec 18, 2024Read More |  Amidst Manchester United exit talk, Marcus Rashford ready for 'new challenge'

Headline: Thanks for not running me out: Finch's witty wish on Ashwin's retirementAUS vs IND: Former Australian captain Aaron Finch wished Ravi Ashwin after the latter announced his retirement from international cricket. Ashwin called time in his career after the Gabba Test against Australia.
Content:

Finch, who played for the Melbourne Renegades in the Big Bash League, recalled an incident where Ashwin gave him a run out warning during an Indian Premier League (IPL) match back in 2020. Back in 2018, Ashwin and Finch played together for PBKS. Finch wrote, “One of the all time careers. Congratulations R Ashwin. It was a pleasure to play with and against you. PS: Thanks for not running me out this day!”

Headline: R Ashwin retires: What pushed India's best red-ball spinner to call it quitsRavichandran Ashwin's decision to retire from international cricket has shaken Indian cricket. Despite being India's best red-ball spinner, non-selection controversies and undervaluation of specialist skills likely influenced his decision.
Content: Could we say this retirement was expected, or is it a surprise? If I had to choose one word, it's a shocker. It feels like a bolt from the blue, primarily because this decision wasn't made by the selectors regarding Ashwin. As Rohit Sharma noted, and as Ravichandran Ashwin himself mentioned, this was a personal decision. Clearly, it's a choice that has come directly from the off-spinner. When does a player decide they've had enough? It's usually when they feel surplus to requirements, believe they're no longer capable of contributing, or sense that their abilities are waning. But truth be told, at this moment, in a country of 1.4 billion people, Ashwin remains unquestionably the best red-ball spinner -- head and shoulders above the rest. And I'm referring strictly to his current form, not relying on his legacy to argue for an extended tenure. The reality is that even if Ashwin were a youngster competing against the other spinners in the country-some of whom are part of the current squad-he would still stand out as India's best red-ball spinner. So, when someone at the peak of their powers decides to retire, it leaves you stunned. When Roger Federer retired, or when Rafael Nadal announced his plans to step away, it was because they'd reached the end of their respective cycles. They were grappling with physical injuries and knew they couldn't compete at the highest level anymore. But that's not the case with Ashwin right now. Just look at the last Test match he played for India, a week ago in Adelaide. He may not have ended up with many wickets, but we must consider that it was a pink-ball Test, with conditions heavily favouring fast bowlers. Despite that, Ashwin impressed as a spinner. Under these circumstances, if he still decides to retire, there's no word other than "shock" to describe it. Now, let’s examine another aspect of this decision that doesn’t quite add up. Ashwin is second on the list of most Test wickets for India, trailing only the great Anil Kumble. How often have we heard of players chasing records? We’ve discussed Virat Kohli’s aspirations to surpass Sachin Tendulkar’s record of 100 centuries. Wasn’t Ashwin similarly chasing the record of being India’s highest Test wicket-taker? After all, Anil Kumble is just 82 wickets ahead of him. With the kind of bowling Ashwin has displayed recently, one could easily imagine him playing another World Test Championship cycle. A couple more years of Test cricket, and it wouldn’t have been far-fetched to see him surpass "Jumbo."WHAT LED TO THE SUDDEN RETIREMENT? So, what led to this abrupt retirement? In the absence of an official word from Ashwin himself, we can only speculate. However, the circumstances surrounding his non-selection cannot be ignored. Ashwin has faced significant disappointment in recent years, consistently being left out of the playing XI despite his form. It’s hard to believe this didn’t weigh on his mind when making this decision. What must have hurt the most is the consistency with which various coaches and captains chose to keep him on the bench, particularly in overseas Tests. Perhaps the events in Australia proved to be the proverbial last straw. Ashwin debuted in 2011, but one can’t help but wonder: had he made his debut a decade earlier—when traditional Test cricket placed greater emphasis on primary skills rather than multi-skilled players—he might have played far more Test matches than he ultimately did. In earlier times, the approach was straightforward: white-ball cricket demanded multi-dimensional players, but Test cricket prioritised primary skills. Outstanding batters or bowlers were always picked. Unfortunately, this thinking seems to have shifted within the Indian setup. Take Australia as an example, particularly Nathan Lyon. Both Lyon and Ashwin are off-spinners of similar stature, yet Lyon remains a consistent feature of Australia’s XI regardless of recent results or conditions. The same courtesy has not been extended to Ashwin in India. Over the past decade, India hasn’t always played its best spinner, often opting instead for one who could contribute with the bat. Small factors in recent series, like Jadeja’s runs in Brisbane and Sundar getting picked in Perth ahead of Ashwin, may have further nudged him towards making this final decision. In the end, the best red-ball spinner in the country called time on his career—not because his powers were waning, but while he was still at the top of his game. This loss is one for Indian cricket to bear.Published By: Saurabh KumarPublished On: Dec 18, 2024Read More |  Rohit Sharma's emotional farewell message for R Ashwin: You are a true OG

Headline: Watch: Retiring R Ashwin's emotional parting speech at Gabba dressing room Australia vs India, 3rd Test: R Ashwin addressed the Indian dressing room, hours after announcing his retirement from international cricket. Content:
All-rounder R Ashwin delivered an emotional parting speech in the Indian dressing room at the Gabba after the end of the third Test of the Border-Gavaskar Trophy. Ashwin said he built great relationships with his teammates, especially over the last 4–5 years, referring to his bond with the likes of Virat Kohli, Rohit Sharma and Ravindra Jadeja.  R Ashwin retired from international cricket in an unforeseen call on Wednesday, December 18. The decision came after India's third Test against Australia in Brisbane ended in a rain-affected draw.  "Even though I am not exhibiting it, it's a truly emotional moment," Ashwin began his speech in the dressing room. "Thanks Rohit, thanks Virat, thanks Gauti bhai. I am so happy today," he added.  Also Read: What influenced R Ashwin's decision to retire midway through Australia tour The off-spinner was also presented with a signed shirt by the members of the Australian cricket team. His nemesis-turned good friend, Nathan Lyon and Australia captain Pat Cummins handed the special shirt to him at the Gabba on Wednesday.  R Ashwin recalled his first Australian tour in 2011-12 and shed light on how he bonded with his teammates over the years.  "It feels like just now I toured Australia for the first time. I saw everybody transition. Rahul paaji left, Sachin paaji left," Ashwin said.  "But, trust me guys, everybody's time comes and it's truly my time. I have thoroughly enjoyed it. I have built some great relationships, especially over the last 4-5 years. I am leaving behind some of my teammates who have been playing with dearly.  "Every passing moment in the last four years, I have realised how much I value their relationship and value them as a player. I have had a great time," he added.

Content:

 Ravichandran Ashwin holds the record for the most wickets for India in the Border-Gavaskar Trophy with a total of 114 wickets. He surpassed legendary spinner Harbhajan Singh, who previously held the record with 32 wickets in a single series in 2001. Also Read: When Rohit convinced Ashwin to play in Adelaide The record for the most wickets taken in a single Border-Gavaskar Trophy series is held by Ravichandran Ashwin, who took 29 wickets during the 2020-21 series played in Australia. This remarkable performance played a crucial role in India's historic 2-1 victory over Australia, marking the first time India won a Test series down under since 2018-19. The legendary India spinner spoke briefly about his decision to retire from all forms of international cricket. "This will be my last day as an Indian cricket in all formats of the game at the international level. I do feel there is a bit of punch left in me as a cricketer. I would like to showcase that in club-level cricket. So this will be my last day. I have had a lot of fun. I must say I've created a lot of memories alongside Rohit and several of my teammates," Ashwin said at the press conference. "Obviously, there are a lot of people to thank. But, I would be failing in my duty if I didn't thank the BCCI and the rest of my teammates. I want to name a few of them and all the coaches -- Rohit, Virat, Ajinkya and Pujara who have taken all those catches in the slips to help me get those wickets."R Ashwin's Career Highlights Ravichandran Ashwin is often referred to as one of the most prolific and versatile cricketers in Indian cricket history. His career, which spanned over a decade, was marked by numerous achievements and contributions that significantly impacted India's performance in international cricket. Ashwin made his Test debut in 2011 against the West Indies and quickly established himself as a key component of India's bowling attack. His ability to take wickets on various surfaces, especially on the turning tracks of the Indian subcontinent, was unparalleled. He holds the record for the most wickets by an Indian bowler in a four-Test series against Australia, with 29 wickets, and was instrumental in several series victories, including the historic 4-0 win against Australia in 2013 and the 3-1 win against England in 2021. Ashwin's impact extended beyond his bowling; he was also a handy lower-order batsman. He scored six Test centuries and amassed over 3,500 runs in Test cricket, making him one of only three cricketers, along with Shane Warne and Stuart Broad, to have taken more than 500 Test wickets and scored over 3,000 Test runs. Ashwin played a crucial role in several major tournament victories for India. He was part of the Indian team that won the 2011 ICC Cricket World Cup and the 2013 ICC Champions Trophy. In the Champions Trophy final, his match figures of 2/15 helped India secure a narrow victory over England. At the domestic level, Ashwin's performances for Tamil Nadu and in the Indian Premier League (IPL) were instrumental in his rise to international prominence. His breakthrough season in the 2010 IPL with Chennai Super Kings, where he took 13 wickets and helped the team win the title, marked the beginning of his successful career. Ashwin's contributions were recognized with several prestigious awards. He was awarded the Arjuna Award in 2014, India's second-highest sporting honor. In 2016, he was named the ICC Cricketer of the Year and the ICC Men's Test Cricketer of the Year, reflecting his dominance in the Test format. Ashwin's retirement from international cricket in December 2024 marks the end of an illustrious career. With 765 wickets across formats, including 537 Test wickets, he is India's second-highest wicket-taker behind Anil Kumble. After losing the ODI series 0-3, the Tigers bounced back strongly to win the T20I series with one game remaining to be played on Thursday, December 19 at the same venue. Gudakesh Motie was the pick of the bowlers after he finished with figures of 4-0-25-2. Akeal Hosein hardly gave anything away, conceding 16 runs in four overs. Roston Chase, Alzarri Joseph and Obed McCoy took one wicket apiece.

Headline: Tendulkar on Ashwin's retirement: One of India's greatest match winnersLegendary Sachin Tendulkar hailed Ravichanadran Ashwin as one of India's greatest match winners. Sachin's comments came after the player's shock retirement decision after the conclusion of the Gabba Test.
Content:

Sachin took to Twitter to pen a heartfelt note for Ashwin, after the spinner announced his shock retirement after the conclusion of the Gabba Test on Wednesday, 18 December. Ashwin was spotted shedding tears in the dressing room alongside Virat Kohli and officially announced his decision in the post match press conference alongside Rohit Sharma. The spinner said that he would address questions about his retirement later on. From perfecting the carrom ball to contributing crucial runs, you always found a way to win. Watching you grow from a promising talent to one of India’s finest match-winners has been wonderful. Your journey shows that true greatness lies in never being afraid to experiment and evolve. Your legacy will inspire one and all. Wishing you all the very best for your 2nd innings," Sachin Tendulkar wrote on Twitter.

His career, which spanned over a decade, was marked by numerous achievements and contributions that significantly impacted India's performance in international cricket. Ashwin made his Test debut in 2011 against the West Indies and quickly established himself as a key component of India's bowling attack. His ability to take wickets on various surfaces, especially on the turning tracks of the Indian subcontinent, was unparalleled. He scored six Test centuries and amassed over 3,500 runs in Test cricket, making him one of only three cricketers, along with Shane Warne and Stuart Broad, to have taken more than 500 Test wickets and scored over 3,000 Test runs. Ashwin played a crucial role in several major tournament victories for India. He was part of the Indian team that won the 2011 ICC Cricket World Cup and the 2013 ICC Champions Trophy. In the Champions Trophy final, his match figures of 2/15 helped India secure a narrow victory over England. At the domestic level, Ashwin's performances for Tamil Nadu and in the Indian Premier League (IPL) were instrumental in his rise to international prominence. His breakthrough season in the 2010 IPL with Chennai Super Kings, where he took 13 wickets and helped the team win the title, marked the beginning of his successful career. Ashwin's contributions were recognized with several prestigious awards. He was awarded the Arjuna Award in 2014, India's second-highest sporting honor. In 2016, he was named the ICC Cricketer of the Year and the ICC Men's Test Cricketer of the Year, reflecting his dominance in the Test format. Ashwin's retirement from international cricket in December 2024 marks the end of an illustrious career. With 765 wickets across formats, including 537 Test wickets, he is India's second-highest wicket-taker behind Anil Kumble. Headline: Soldier's son from Virender Sehwag's school selected for Vijay Merchant TrophyRahul Soreng, son of the late Pulwama hero Vijay Soreng, has made it to the Haryana Under-16 team for the Vijay Merchant Trophy. A proud moment celebrated by Virender Sehwag, showcasing the power of opportunity and resilience.
Content:
In a proud and emotional moment, former Indian cricketer Virender Sehwag shared the inspiring journey of Rahul Soreng, son of late Pulwama hero Vijay Soreng. Rahul has been selected for the Haryana Under-16 team in the prestigious Vijay Merchant Trophy. This marked a significant achievement in his budding cricket career. Rahul’s story is closely tied to Sehwag International School, where he has been a student since 2019. Following the tragic Pulwama attack, Sehwag made an exceptional gesture by offering free education and boarding to the children of fallen soldiers. This initiative aimed to honour the sacrifices of India’s brave hearts and provide their children with opportunities to excel in life. Rahul’s selection stands as a shining example of how support and opportunities can help young talent thrive. Taking to X, Sehwag expressed his joy, calling it one of the happiest feelings of his life. He wrote, “I feel so privileged that Rahul Soreng, son of Pulwama hero Shaheed Vijay Soreng ji, who joined Sehwag International School in 2019, has been with us for the last four years and has now been selected in the Haryana Under-16 team for the Vijay Merchant Trophy. Few things give more joy. Thank you to our great soldiers.”Sehwag's tweet

Headline: Pat Cummins praises 'all-time great' R Ashwin on retirement AUS vs IND: Pat Cummins said that he was surprised after R Ashwin announced his retirement from international cricket. Ashwin took the call after the Gabba Test against Australia in Brisbane.
Content:
Pat Cummins said that he was taken aback after R Ashwin retired from international cricket. On Wednesday, Ashwin pulled the curtains down on his career following the Gabba Test against Australia. Ashwin didn’t play the Perth Test, but returned for the Adelaide Test, where he took only a solitary wicket. After being left out of the third Test in Brisbane, Ashwin called time on his illustrious career. Ashwin retired as the seventh-highest wicket-taker in Test cricket and the second-highest for India after the legendary Anil Kumble. Cummins said that Ashwin will go down as one of the greatest cricketers to have played the game given the time his career spanned. “Bit of a surprise. He has obviously been a fantastic player. There aren’t too many finger spinners who have that kind of longevity. He will go down as one of the all-time greats. He has always been a fantastic competitor. We have had a lot of battles against him over the years in Australia as well as in India. Massive respect from our dressing room for the career that he has had,” Cummins said in the post-match press conference.
